content.raw: Thanks for the fix! Do you have a link to the place in simspark where the coordinates are calculated? It would be nice to put it here to be used as reference in the future. Thanks!

pullrequest.title: Adjusted vision perception to match SimSpark convention.

content.raw:
I don't know exactly where the calculation is located in the SimSpark server - but I can try to find out. Until then I have a link to the SimSpark Wiki, where I described the coordinate system of the vision perception: http://simspark.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Perceptors#Vision_Perceptors

Maybe some other teams can check if their localization algorithms work without any change after my fix?
content.html:
I don't know exactly where the calculation is located in the SimSpark server - but I can try to find out. Until then I have a link to the SimSpark Wiki, where I described the coordinate system of the vision perception: http://simspark.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Perceptors#Vision_Perceptors

pullrequest.title: Adjusted vision perception to match SimSpark convention.

content.raw: This fix seems to fix the problem I was having of not being able to localize.  Our agent can now chase (slowly) after the ball!  To get things to work I have to prevent our agent from panning its head from side to side however...maybe there's a sign flip in the azimuth value?  Maybe the agent isn't receiving the same information about its head's joint angle as it does in simspark?
content.html: This fix seems to fix the problem I was having of not being able to localize. Our agent can now chase (slowly) after the ball! To get things to work I have to prevent our agent from panning its head from side to side however...maybe there's a sign flip in the azimuth value? Maybe the agent isn't receiving the same information about its head's joint angle as it does in simspark?

thanks for confirming the fix.

2. 20 degrees head angle (with some arm yaw joints nonzero):

pullrequest.title: Adjusted vision perception to match SimSpark convention.

content.raw:
The problem with panning the head (yaw) is in the model.  If I make the following sign change to the z axis (changing -1 to 1) of the head yaw in nao_Type_0.sdf things work correctly for vision when panning the head:

```
    <joint name='HeadYaw' type='revolute'>
      <child>Neck</child>
      <parent>base_link</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
```
content.html:
The problem with panning the head (yaw) is in the model. If I make the following sign change to the z axis (changing -1 to 1) of the head yaw in nao_Type_0.sdf things work correctly for vision when panning the head:

    <joint name='HeadYaw' type='revolute'>
      <child>Neck</child>
      <parent>base_link</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>

content.raw:
Yes, it seems like this axis got a flipped sign. It also looks more reasonable to have a positive one here instead of an negative one. I can confirm that your suggestion fixes this issue and have a screenshot of it if you like (but I already posted three...).
If you like, I'll add it to my pull request. However, I first need to check out how to do this ;)

content.raw:
hi @umscht , thanks for the patch. 

Could you fix this minor style error catched by the style checker?


```
#!c++

./src/Geometry.cc:134:  Lines should be <= 80 characters long  [whitespace/line_length] [2]
Total errors found: 1
```

Otherwise, looks good to me.
